Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of High Speed Video Imaging System for Electromagnetic Shockwave Control and Shockwave-Boundary Layer Interaction Research at AAMU

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1337227
Deng

The objective of this proposal is to acquire a high-speed video imaging system for the Mach 4 supersonic wind tunnel at Alabama A&M University (AAMU). The imaging system will enable researchers to conduct electromagnetic shockwave control and shockwave/boundary layer interaction research, both require capturing the shockwave location and movement near the area of extreme heat fluxes where the shockwave is typically oscillating at 1kHz to 20 kHz frequency. The AAMU supersonic wind tunnel is a state-of-the-art facility for shockwave experiments. This wind tunnel facility can provide stable air at speed of Mach 4 for 20 seconds within 6x6x18 inch test section. The existing instrumentation for the wind tunnel includes a sting balance, an optical imaging Schlieren system and a computer controlled high speed data acquisition system with 48 channels. However, this wind tunnel system does not have any high speed imaging capability, which is critical to the supersonic shockwave interaction research. The proposed project will acquire a high-speed high-resolution digital video system, the Phantom V1210 camera, made by Vision Research. It is the necessary instrument for the supersonic wind tunnel facility. It will immediately enable the research in electromagnetic control of shockwave and shockwave-boundary layer interaction using AAMU?s Supersonic wind tunnel.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to acquire a high-speed video imaging system for the Mach 4 supersonic wind tunnel at Alabama A&M University (AAMU). This imaging system will enable researchers to conduct shockwave control and shockwave/boundary layer interaction research; both requiring capture of the shockwave location and movement near the area of extreme heat. The AAMU supersonic wind tunnel is a state-of-the-art facility for shockwave experiments. This wind tunnel facility can provide stable air at Mach 4 for 20 seconds within 6x6x18 inch test section. This high speed video imaging system provides a critical instrument required for shockwave control and shockwave/boundary layer interaction research. 

An open bid process for the acquisition of the high speed video system was created. The specification of the major requirements for a high speed video imaging system was released to four equipment vendors.  Bidders were required to provide all items in writing with descriptions where necessary to help AAMU better understand the bidder’s goods and services offered. Bidders were also required to explicitly compare the functional and performance specifications of their offering with each specification item. Bidders were required to provide warranty information in their response along with an itemized list of components.

The open bid was concluded and the high speed imaging system made by Vision Research, the Phantom V1210 was selected. This high speed video imaging system has a frame rate of 12,000 frames per second (fps) at the full resolution of 1Mega Pixel (Mp). This system has a 12 bit ADC precision, the capability to record at faster frame rates up to one million frames per second at lower resolution, on-board memory of 96 GB, with 144GB additional high speed data download CineMag on-board storage. The imaging system has capability to interchange objective lenses using standard NIKON lens mounts. It can be externally triggered through Cameral control software and has the capability for data time marking by an external source.

The high speed video imaging system is fully functional. Faculty members, undergraduate engineering students were trained to use the imaging system to conduct fluid mechanics laboratory experiments, the investigation of vortex shedding behind a cylinder in a low speed water tunnel experiment. Benchmark shockwave formation experiments were conducted for Mach 1.5, Mach 2 and Mach 3.75 using the high speed video imaging system in the supersonic wind tunnel. A high speed video imaging system and supersonic wind tunnel testing capability description was created and presented to various government agencies and private aerospace companies.

The acquisition of a high speed video imaging system has strengthened the supersonic propulsion education at AAMU for minority graduate and undergraduate students. Research collaboration between the researchers and local industries was greatly enhanced by acquisition of the instrument. 


Last Modified: 10/06/2014
Modified by: Zhengtao Deng
